segments.text: I have the pleasure of talking to Bob Lacey, an old colleague, and want to chat with him about his experiences as one of the key people at A&M for a number of years.
First, Bob, give us a brief summary of your biography up until you go to work at A&M.
Where did you grow up?
When did you get to A&M?
What did you major in?
And so forth.
Okay.
Well, I grew up in Centerville, Texas.
Born October 6, 1937.
Went to public school in Centerville.
Centerville is a small community of about 800 people in Leon County.
How many in the senior class?
28 in the senior class.
I remarked there, we've never been anywhere.
Chartered a bus to New Orleans and had our senior trip down there and was evicted out of
two hotels in three days.
But I graduated from high school in 1956 and came to Texas A&M in the fall of 1956 and majored in mathematics, which I got my degree in.
Graduated in three and a half years, finished in January of 1960.

I really didn't know what I wanted to do, and my father, having been in the school business when he was a young man, he said, look, I always feel that a teaching certificate's a good thing for a person to have that particularly doesn't know what they want to do.
So I stayed an extra semester and picked up the education courses that qualified me for a teaching certificate.
I left A&M in the fall of 60 and went down to Cypress Fairbanks High School.
I taught math there for two years and decided that I wanted to get a graduate degree, primarily in the field of educational administration because I thought that I might make public school a career.
And I received a leave of absence.
from Tractor's Firebank, which I'm still on.
And I came to A&M and needed some help in getting the finances for the master's degree.
So I went over and knocked on Dr. Klippel's door.
Dr. Klippel was head of the math department at that time.
This would have been in the fall or the summer, rather, of 1961.
And he said, yeah, we can use you as a teaching assistant.
So they gave me a teaching assistant job, and I enrolled in the Master of Education Administration program.
And I was a teaching assistant for two years, I believe, and graduated with my degree in 1963.
And I still didn't know what I wanted to do, so Dr. Clipple
indicated that I'd done a good job for him.
He said, look, would you like to be put on as an instructor?
I said, well, sure.
So he gave me an instructor job.
And I was one of the few that had the good fortune of being housed in Bagley Hall in my office.
Bagley, you remember where Bagley was?
But describe it for those who... Well, Bagley Hall was located over about where the...
in the area where the Harrington Building is, or a little bit north of there, actually.
And that's where the water tower was located on campus.
And it was an old brick building, two stories, that had been there forever.
Just like that building in the scene.
And in the fall, excuse me, in the fall of 1964,
After I finished my degree, I got a telephone call one day from Mr. Heaton, who was in the registrar.
No, no, no.
You were getting a call from Mr. Heaton?
Oh, yeah.
In December of 64, I got a telephone call from Mr. Heaton.
and said that my name had been recommended to him as a possible replacement for an assistant registrar in the records section, and he'd like to talk to me.

So I go over before the Christmas holidays and sit down and visit with him, and they had this opening, and he said, you have been recommended to me by the chairman of your master's committee and a couple of the committee members, which might be a possibility.
And I'd like to talk to you about the job.
Well, what the job entailed was maintaining the records of all of the students and the former students, the academic members, the former students, me and him.
And it came quite a shock to me because I'd never done anything like this.
I was really looking kind of forward to maybe getting back to the Cypress Firebank area in the second year or so.
Anyway, I told him, I said, look, I need to think about this.
I really don't know.
I'm going off on a deer hunt down in South Texas, and while I'm out there in the woods, well, I'll be thinking.
So I did, and what really had me puzzled was I knew nothing about any kind of administration.
I worked in basically agriculture and teaching school.
That's about all I've done.
But anyway, I thought about it for a long time, and I came back and I talked to two or three of my old professors around here, and they said, look, it's an opportunity to take it.
It doesn't work out.
So I accepted the job and went to work in the registrar's office at the Central Registrar February 1, 1965.
How much was that beginning salary?
The beginning salary was, well, I was making $600 a month in the math department,
And I was promised my same amount of money when I got over to the administration.
But my first check, my salary was cut from $600 to $550 a month.
And I never did really know the reason for that.
But anyway, that was the wishes of the administrator in charge.
And so I was happy with that.
Describe the admissions and records
staff and function when you joined?

Okay, the entire operation was housed in the Richard Koch building on the first floor north side across the hall from the fiscal office and we occupied the basement, commonly referred to as the catacombs.
We occupied half of the basement, actually.
So we had half of the basement and half of the first floor.
At that time, we had a registrar and director of admissions.
Mr. Eaton carried both times.
And we had an associate registrar, Ray Perriman, and an assistant registrar, Bob Lacey.
And we had one
excuse me, at that time we did not.
Mr. Eaton was handling all of the admissions with the exception of Caroline Mitchell.
Caroline Mitchell was an assistant director of admissions and she was in charge among many other duties she had.
She was in charge of all the transfer, the undergraduate transfer.
Reckon how many years of experience of A&M those people represented?
At that time
I'd say close to a hundred.
Because they'd all been here.
Because they'd all been there for a long, long, long time.
Describe their personality and their each of them and their style of doing the job.
Mr. Heaton was a very, very kind and considerate gentleman to work for.
I found him as far as
supervision with me, which I like very much.
He expected us to get our job done, yet he didn't constantly stay close to us.
He gave me a job and we were to do it, and we did it.
He always gave us the strong support and the backup that we needed.
Caroline Mitchell
was a very strong-willed personality lady.

Caroline had a number of functions, and this will probably shock you when you think about what we have today, but not only was she in charge of the transfer students, she was in charge of building the master schedule of classes.
She was the editor of the catalog.
She assigned all of the classroom teaching space on the campus.
And she ran the summer orientation, the freshman orientation conferences.
She had two clerical type .
Mr. Perriman was the associate registrar, and of course I reported to him for a while.
And his basic
responsibilities had to do with the overall operation of the registrar's office related to the record section.
And I guess his main responsibility, which was quite heavy in those days, was the residency factor.
hadn't determined whether or not a student was to have residence, had state residency, or whether to be classified as a resident.
And then he was also, over all the clerical functions that aided him, residency as well.
And also he was in charge of graduation, too.
I forgot about that, which at that time was quite a chore because of the way in which he was.
The enrollment at Texas A&M in 1965, if my memory serves me correctly, was somewhere, I think, around 8,000 to 10,000, maybe 12,000.
I'm not too certain about that.
We hadn't grown a whole lot.
We were coming out of the era of all-male, all-military change in 1963, so a few years after that.
Who did the admissions?
Mr. Heaton did most of the admissions.
Shortly after I came, they did hire another admissions assistant.
It was a fellow by the name of Bob Gleason.
Bob handled the freshman undergraduates, and Caroline handled the transfer students.

Of course, as you well know, graduate admissions, although our office was responsible for the record keeping of the applications of Bob and Lewis and all that sort of stuff, that determination was made in the graduate college.
Now, all of the technological
work was done on typewriters then?
All of it.
All of it.
Was some of it done by hand still?
No.
Well, when I came there, the posting of the academic record, I assume that's basically one of the main things.
The posting of the academic record was done by punch cards
down at the computer center, being generated on each student after the professor turned in their grades.
The grades at that time were turned in on IBM cards, but they were written in.
In other words, Joe Doe in Math 102, Section 500, the professor would put his grade on there and sign his name.
And also at that time, we kept absentees on all of our students.
Those IBM cards were then key punched.
at the computer center.
The data punched in, geared to the student identification number, and then were sorted in order of the student's name.
And all of these were taking six courses and they all came together under his name.
And at that time, all of the permanent academic records were transported to the computer center by means of the assistant registrar
And at night, these were run, and you'd have to stay there for security reasons.
And each one of these things were then printed on the student's academic record.
Quite a horrendous task.
And one of the first things that I got interested in was a faster and better way to do that.
So I was able to do a lot of visitations and whatnot, find what they call a heat transfer posting method.
And that permitted us then to have a carbon tape run at the computer center after these shorts were made.
And then we could post the records in our office, and that stopped us from having to take them out.
And it was done in one swoop, one stamp, and the entire semester was on the students' records.
How long did that run take?
To do it by heat transfer, we could do it in about three or four days, as opposed to about two weeks of what they were doing earlier.
And obviously that speeded up the delivery of transcripts that students were in great need for at the end of the semester.
We started to give much faster turnaround on our transcripts.

One thing that I think might be interesting in this that I forgot to tell you when I was hired, the reason that I was hired was that the assistant registrar that was in charge, or that had the position that Mr. Heaton talked to me about,
had taken a bribe from some of our foreign students at that time to change grades.
And in time this surfaced and charges were brought against the Assistant Registrar and there was a trial and he was given a suspended sentence I think for five to six years.
Mr. Rutter, of course, was the president of the university at that time.
And when Mr. Heaton made the offer to me, he told me that there would be a complete investigation of my background from day one until now, now being in 65.
And I said fine.
I thought I could withstand that.

Several years after that, after I got to know a lot of people around there, particularly the folks over at security, Chief Ed Powell, who was chief of security at that time, and I were having coffee one day, and he said, Bob, he said, I know you real well now, and he said, I'm going to tell you something.
He said, what's that?
He said, Mr. Rutter ordered an investigation of you by the FBI, the Texas Department of Public Safety,

the Brazos County Sheriff's Department and our security here, and said in all those years from date of birth until 1965, we found that you had a speeding ticket issued to you between Austin and San Antonio in 1957.
I said, that is correct.
And so it was quite a, obviously, Mr. Rutter, this caused the university a lot of embarrassment, as you can well imagine.
So he wanted to be sure and having, as you well know, the military background he had, I think that made it even more important to him that this check be done.
All of us that knew Mr. Heaton knew him as a very special person.
When did he begin his work with the university?
Do you know?
I think it was in the very late 30s or early 40s.
Mr. Heaton got his undergraduate degree, I believe, at Stephen F. Austin State University in Nacogdoches, and he came here to get a master's degree.
He was enrolled in a master's program here, and I believe began work in the registrar's office at that time, and was hired

I am not I'm not certain that he came as an assistant or if he just had part-time work but I believe he followed a man named Charlie Friday as a regular guard so late 30s or early 40s for me as a junior faculty member in the 60s I thought apparently he had come at the beginning of time well it seemed like he's been here forever right
I never saw him without a tie on, his shirt and tie.
I never thought of him as engaging in much small talk, but I never was around him when he wasn't pleasant.
Always pleasant.
You're absolutely correct.
As a matter of fact, the few times that I saw Mr. Heaton without a coat and tie on, I felt like he was somewhat undressed.

uh he just he didn't look right he looked like a person that wore glasses all the time and didn't have them on sometimes deeply religious man very very religious very heavily involved in the first magic church and pride and likewise his wife also uh very kind i suppose if i had a
Mr. Heaton had many, many qualities, good qualities.

I suppose if I had to fault him, and he and I talked about this from time to time, and I think it's one of the things that he admired about me, and you know how direct I am, and sometimes that's gotten me into trouble, but Mr. Heaton would avoid, he did not like controversy, and he would do everything he could to avoid it, in my opinion, to a fault, because I felt at times that
He should have said, look, I've got to draw the line, and this is the way it's got to be, and that sort of thing.
And maybe that was from his upbringing, his religious background, or whatever.
He did, in my opinion, I felt like he did.
Maybe, for a better word, he got Steve Rosen.
Now, as you started out, did you get any indoctrination, any training?
As a new professional member of the staff?

Haskell, when I walked in that office, which was located in the basement, that's where the record section was at that time, and looked at that desk, I felt like I should go upstairs and resign immediately because when this man was terminated for his acts,

everything was left and then you see it had been like three months and they didn't have anybody that was there as a supervisor mr perriman was doing the best he could but he was spread real thin with his other job and uh it was more or less you know here it is you've got to straighten it up and we can help we'll help you if you can so
Not to be critical, but it would just get in there and roll your sleeves up and try to figure out what needs to be done.
It was in a mess, and it took quite a bit of time to get it organized.
I've always been fortunate in my entire work at A&M.
Fortunate in the sense that if I looked good, it was because I had good people that I was surrounded by.
And I had wonderful clerical ladies there that
They were looking for someone to give them some direction and they were ready to work.
Now, a typical Heaton work week, what was, how long did he, what time, what time did he get there and leave?
Mr. Heaton would be there sometimes, most mornings between 7 and 7.30 and he would leave between 6 and 6.30.

uh always if he took a lunch hour unless he had some kind of a lunching engagement and he went home every day for lunch if he could of course he had his wife her health was not good and he would go home to look in on her but he used to always tell me that what made his day was that he could go home
have a great bite to eat.
He could stretch out in his Strider lounger and get 15 minutes of a nap.
But he was back at 1 o'clock every single day.
Now, he reported directly then to... At that time, he reported to Wayne Heidel.
No, he reported to Bill Graff.
Bill Graff.
Bill had a title at that time of Dean of Instruction.
I assume if you had to...
acquainted with today, it would be somewhat near a provost position, although the provost today has much wider responsibilities.
But he was the number two man at the university at that time.
Dr. Graff was fully directed to the president.
Alright, now does Wayne Hall follow him?
Wayne Hall, let's see, Dr. Hall
was not Dean of the Graduate College at that time.
I believe Paul Trotter.
All right, Hall would be later Vice President of Academic Affairs and Dean of the Graduate College.
And Bill Barzak was his number two, and I worked halftime up there.
That's correct.
That came after.
Okay, after.
That came after, yeah.
So Mr. Heaton and the staff reported to Graff, Graff to Rutter.
That's correct.
And all of those people, the offices were all there in the Koch building.
That's a good point.
I didn't finish while ago.
The other part of the Koch building was occupied upon the, starting with the second floor.
Mr. Rutter was in the president's office.
Southeast corner.
Exactly.
And then on the southwest corner of that building was where Dean Graff was, or Bill Graff was.
Across the hall...
Directly across the hall from the entrance into Dr. Grant's office was the faculty room.
And the faculty room was where large meetings were held, but it was primarily for the academic council.
The academic council at that time was made up of all the presidents, the deans, and the department heads.
And I guess it would be somewhat of a forerunner to the faculty senate.
Now, who else was down on the first floor?
And on the, let's see, who was in the office?
You know, there's another office up there where Howard Wester was.
Remember where Howard was?
Who was in that office?
Was that the graduate dean?
The graduate dean, that's correct, the graduate dean.
Then down on your floor?
Down on my floor on the south half of the first floor was the fiscal office.
And that's where Clark Diebel and his staff, plus they occupied the basement directly under that on the south side of the building.
All right.
Share with me from the 60s, if you can, had the first black students gotten here
Of course, when I was in school here, there were no blacks at all.
The first time that I can recall of blacks was about 1964-65.
There was no discussion whatsoever that I was aware of about their admission.

As I understand, Mr. Rutter called the Pentagon, and the Pentagon, at his request, when they sent that year's group of enlisted Army to work on their degree at Pentagon expense, some of them were black, and they began in summer school.
I believe that is correct.
Wasn't that under the National Science Foundation program?
I think so.
And that Mr. Heaton was told by Rutter, so I understand,
to call each faculty member a day in advance and say, tomorrow when you meet class, you will have a black student there.
Don't worry.
There is no reason this student has been admitted, is fully competent.
And there was not a single problem.
And so when the fall semester began, nobody could say it wouldn't work.
It worked nicely that summer.
I can't respond to the calling that you indicated, Mr. Heathman.
I'm not aware of it.
Having not been in admissions at that time, I could have been certainly left out of that.
I can tell you that there were absolutely no incidents.
Yeah, I never heard of it.
The only incident that I'm aware of, and this was some couple of years or so after the time period you're talking about, was the
One night in the library there were some blacks who had checked out some books and there was something very minor about how they returned the books or that sort of thing.
Very little talk and no demonstrations of any kind that I'm aware of at all.
All right.
What about some anecdotes about the admission of women gradually becoming more and more inclusive?
Do you remember any?
Well, one of the main things that I remember was that, as you well know, at that time, all of our registrations were being held in Subesa's dining hall.
And there was a card in the registration packet that the females had to sign.
And it had to be notarized by someone in the line of registration.
We would hire eight, ten notary publics.
It would be right at the end of the exit of Subesa, and the student left to turn their packet in.

And on those cards would be questions like, do you solemnly swear that you are a daughter of a faculty or a staff member, and that you cannot find this program at any other institution in the United States, and I don't know two or three other things.
So I remember that side of it.
After the 1963
And when Mr. Runner made his decision, you know, there were dislikes from the admission of women to Texas A&M.
You could know, I think, about the stories of former students that were unhappy and some of them took their Aggie rings off and didn't wear them again, that sort of thing.
But internally in the office, no discussion.
No discussion at all about it.
I think it was accepted that
It took a while for the female enrollment to grow, but I don't recall any.
Okay, now let's move on forward with your career as your duties tell me about how they grew and personnel changed.
Well, in 1967, I guess, yeah, two years after I'd been there,
I was talking with Mr. Heaton constantly all this time about we have to do something with Mr. Heaton.
Mr. Heaton, bless his heart, was not of the computer age.
Back to your earlier statement about a lot of it was being done by hand.
It was basically all being done by hand.
And there had been a horrible relationship between the Office of Admissions and Records and the Data Processing Center.
There was some bad feeling there.
Most of it was done prior to my time, so I can't give you a whole lot of history about it, except I do think that part of it was simply because of the bid.
The individuals that were there, that had been there for so many years and had been doing it a particular way, simply bucked them.
They didn't want to change.
And they didn't want to change a lot, I think, because they had not had the good fortune to have been educated in what computers could do.
And so part of my
A good number of my responsibilities, of course, was working with the data processing center.
And I'll never forget the first time I walked in that building down there.
It was ice.
I mean, it was obvious to me immediately that there was some real problems between our office and the computer center.
I worked hard down there, and I had taken computer courses myself, so that helped my relationship with the computer center, and particularly Bob Smith, who was the director of it at that time.
I got well acquainted with him and told him that this is my mission, this is what I want to do, and I'm working on the other end up here with Mr. Eaton to get this done.
And so Bob Smith often referred to me as being...
their salvation in the registrar's office.
So it took me a while, but we got that.
